912495E652544723B1C287E5248F4752.description: Describe media influences on their perceptions of people and places in Canada.

23BEBACE68214782A64A11EF8CBDA506.description: Identify various ways in which governments help people meet their needs. Examples: education, health care, sanitation.

4F838F7532044C9BAEDA341C7CC73009.description:
Use examples to distinguish between public
and private property.

1E9DDA3496F74C9B89E447C40947DA1A.description: Respect the rights of others when using personal power or authority. Examples: as a member of cooperative groups, patrols, class monitors, conflict managers.

BEC8AE996805478EBEBA436241101B55.description: Identify positive ways of dealing with conflict or the misuse of power and authority.

E343B8AC0014443AA33D199B167FB4EC.description: Give examples of formal and informal power and authority in their lives. Examples: rules, laws, student councils, bullying, gangs.

60CB4EE04F364110B5489F089FD70D76.description: Identify elected representatives of their Aboriginal communities.

0439B6FEBEEE41509BCF55E2226115FB.description: Recognize that there are elected Aboriginal representatives in Manitoba and in Canada.

18333837DB2B4278B189912EDFD564A2.description: Identify elected government leaders in their local communities, in Manitoba, and in Canada.

C2C6C98369BB424C9387038AF1118D85.description: Identify levels of government in Canada and give examples of their responsibilities. Include: municipal or local, provincial or territorial, First Nation, and federal governments.

E1BEC7BCB0BE4B88BBB47707D9C37C0D.description: Appreciate Manitoba’s interdependence with the world.

C6DAB1DD56A84AF1BB9CF918B1874DBB.description: Recognize that personal decisions and actions can affect people elsewhere in the world. Examples: UNICEF, Project Love, recycling projects.

37BE8E266E9940E7BD4217237FBED2E3.description:
Identify ways in which the people of
Manitoba are connected to other people in the
world.
Examples: immigration, imports and exports,
travel.

2A51FCE7F36047239830023D893E3DF0.description: Appreciate the significance of history in their lives.

CD44D025724F4BCE99F3764E6C99D11E.description: Value oral tradition as an important way to learn history.

8C9A06A3CB5F4DA5BDF6CE447056EA89.description: Describe changes in ways of life in the last century in the northern territory studied. Examples: food, clothing, transportation, languages, recreation, education.

BA333A2897514F41946FAA637F8CA3BF.description: Identify the main reasons for the creation of Nunavut and the new Northwest Territories.

25800E3AF71940C385DB91D1CEEE953B.description: Give examples of stories and traditions of the northern territory studied.

0805F36358AD43F6AFFC50F9D90990BB.description: Describe ways in which life in Manitoba has changed over time. Examples: housing, food, hunting and fishing, clothing, recreation, languages, education, agriculture, transportation.

AC9F6AFC51EE479C8B323CACECF767AE.description: Give examples of the impact of European settlement on Aboriginal communities in Manitoba. Include: displacement of communities, disease, cultural change.

5DC896D06E124664ABDDCEEE559DC58F.description:
Relate stories of people and events that
shaped Manitoba.
Examples: voyageurs, Louis Riel, Chief
Peguis, Lord Selkirk, Nellie McClung,
Thanadelthur, bison hunt.

07BFA6972F154B16AE76EE657A6C30E1.description: Value the contributions of the North to the Canadian community.

88064D27792B409C94AA57B67B4456A1.description: Respect their spiritual connection to the natural environment (land, water, sky).

BAD1ECA66AEE4C50902E685A496701F6.description: Appreciate Canada’s vast and diverse geography.

3410075BE04E43A4A05A8E687F43D143.description: Describe various purposes of inuksuit. Examples: companionship; to mark food caches, hunting locations, direction.

52DBAD5DB6134837B3B6BBF7B3BE7CFD.description: Give examples of changes to place names in the northern territory studied. Examples: Kugluktuk/Coppermine.

5A751FE7F0F8498B9D90B37B0A952994.description: Describe the demographic features of the northern territory studied. Examples: population, population distribution.

01A7746F12C445A59F725235075D28F4.description: Identify natural resources in the northern territory studied.

BFF2C3989A634F3BBFA45344DB39A017.description: Locate on a map and describe physical features of the northern territory studied.

DB81CB9B1DA740628E80A415689D59E5.description: Relate stories of interactions between the Selkirk settlers and Aboriginal peoples.

1944EA9B9FAF42DFB0F3504C2D22BC3B.description: Describe the influence of the natural environment on settlement in Manitoba.

B605ABBE190041CC9128A305AC0EE6B2.description: Describe places of historic, cultural, or environmental significance in Manitoba. Examples: Lower Fort Garry, the Forks, musée de Saint-Boniface, Thunderbird House, provincial/national parks.

EC8B87FC8BB74EE1AAA5C39A15709A17.description: Give examples of Aboriginal peoples’ traditional relationships with the land.

16F8C08FAB8E482BB56091ED09CDD5CA.description: Identify issues related to environmental stewardship and sustainability in Manitoba.

3897161B4FEC4B49911DAD441BC9149C.description: Describe the main demographic features of Manitoba. Include: population, population distribution, cultural communities.

5CC41C1A5EE04FC1B7445E18D808DFB4.description: Locate on a map and identify major natural resources in Manitoba.

B3B97A53DF904F3CB5E57F627FF5F4E5.description: Use traditional knowledge to describe and locate places in Manitoba.

501E327D11634FDABDD50D353E68229F.description: Locate on a map and describe geographic features of Manitoba. Examples: lakes and rivers, landforms, vegetation, forests, parks, cities and towns, First Nations communities.

5A32C6AC33EC4875AC6F001465BF2F3A.description: Locate the provinces, territories, and capital cities on a map of Canada.

A64C2A1C207D474B8C74624B1591484D.description: Locate the oceans, major landforms, lakes, and waterways on a map of Canada.

56F24F9E29B2446EB3206E405672EE81.description: Describe characteristics of the geographic regions of Canada. Examples: landforms, bodies of water, vegetation, climate, population distribution.

96C3C33A2AFF4A998F03496FAAD87EB1.description: Locate the geographic regions on a map of Canada. Examples: Western Cordillera, Prairie Region, Canadian Shield, St. Lawrence - Great Lakes Lowlands, Atlantic Region, Arctic Region.

2C0896E48ED14A95B55439EE95BC2964.description:
Describe the relative locations of Manitoba
and Canada in the world using cardinal
directions.

0CA62CA92D3240C989887FA1896E4A14.description: Value the artistic and cultural achievements of Manitobans.

64363355541A428AAFAC3FDF00092F0D.description: Value ethnic and cultural diversity in Manitoba.

E3AD09FA7E68400884C7BDBB5C8C814D.description: Give examples of Aboriginal languages, cultures, and communities in the northern territory studied.

1D105E2878274E42A53F1300F0059E32.description: Describe Aboriginal contributions to the northern territory studied. Examples: visual arts, games, music, dance.

C455D248416942D1B488202AEAB21642.description: Recognize that their identities are connected to the history of their francophone community.

AFAC66FE802E431A89B46700015F680A.description: Give examples of francophone contributions to the history of Manitoba. Examples: settlement of Saint-Boniface, place names, language and culture, voyageurs.

55C0AD4CDB5142919D6BE89349BEAA1C.description: Recognize that their identities are connected to the history of their Aboriginal community.

95819A9EE81A47A7AC758644A1D1B2DC.description: Give examples of Aboriginal contributions to the history of Manitoba. Examples: place names, art, parks and historic sites, symbols and stories, guidance to early settlers.

95067C0A081E408A992D44506D165103.description: Give examples of the contributions of diverse ethnic and cultural communities to the history of Manitoba.

FBE492F3A5ED4417B28E88A31A7E092E.description: Describe the influence of their cultural heritage on their francophone identity.

F9E3FDC0E4E04F38A69ACFF45E77ACA9.description: Understand the teachings of Elders about their culture and identity.

46BEB1DC2E894940AAEECE85CFB9EECF.description: Describe the influence of various factors on their identities. Include: culture, community, place, region.

FD5D53DF11C642EAA615DDF251D41C27.description: Identify connections between their local community and other francophone communities in Manitoba.

EAD84BD1087748048265E740749CDF5B.description: Identify connections between their community and other Aboriginal communities in Manitoba.

9C0340873E994DC596D32685AFF010FC.description: Identify Aboriginal communities, cultures, and languages in Manitoba. Examples: Cree, Ojibway, Dakota, Michif, Oji-Cree, Dene.

E83C0F69A9DE4D3BA3647BC91C4905B2.description: Give examples of francophone artistic and cultural achievements and organizations in Manitoba.

CD16F217BFDC432F9F23BD4E8B27C88F.description: Give examples of Aboriginal artistic and cultural achievements and organizations in Manitoba.

934C4DA74FBF4EDE8E935997CB9CE01F.description: Give examples of diverse artistic and cultural achievements of Manitobans. Include: Aboriginal and francophone cultural achievements.

B2B41CBADB7F485A8584A3A1159E8A6F.description: Be willing to contribute to their groups and communities.

56E047715A894B90A5F17037EF84C37F.description: Explain from a personal perspective what it means to be a francophone citizen in Canada.

0E79D57D7BED4B91AD4E29F3733E87CC.description: Explain from a personal perspective what it means to be an Aboriginal citizen in Canada.

50D81B277D4541AB92D2A54438B51C55.description: Explain from a personal perspective what it means to be a citizen of Canada.

C9B2FB0446B442DC89222387781766D5.description: Identify days important to Canadians and Manitobans. Examples: Canada Day, Remembrance Day, National Aboriginal Day, St. Jean Baptiste Day, Manitoba Day, Louis Riel Day.

CBE23C4298DE45148DE649B943BA9D3C.description: Identify democratic ideals in Canadian society. Examples: equality, freedom, citizen participation in government.

9F106AA0CA4F43FDBF06EBBE2257DD63.description:
Describe Canadian and provincial or
territorial symbols and monuments.
Examples: national anthem, coats of arms,
flags, monuments, legislative buildings.

E9FC14D7066D4A75A3E39B0F90D67840.description: Present information and ideas orally, visually, concretely, or electronically.

CF1E9E0B10774FD99219B8F9248D181B.description: Support their ideas and opinions with information or observations.

75734BC0209B470E87C933CDD7769F40.description: Use language that is respectful of human diversity.

4AF2768D4A204214BFCDB34CA94B5EAF.description:
Listen actively to others to understand their
perspectives.

D3A45018B7D3476582CD192A78C8066D.description: Observe and analyze material or visual evidence for research. Examples: artifacts, photographs, works of art.

B414BA1D65A14AD480BC0CCB3644D53C.description: Evaluate personal assumptions based on new information and ideas.

8AD842711C7D42499E5292918AB46723.description: Draw conclusions based on information and evidence.

AC2E56BF98CB4FE8B67BA4A1C8B57416.description: Consider advantages and disadvantages of solutions to a problem.

109FE487D9D34B5A9BD5B21DD9D5ED34.description: Orient themselves by observing the landscape, using traditional knowledge, or using a compass or other tools and technologies. Examples: sun, moon, or stars, inuksuit, Global Positioning Systems (GPS).

5BA8E8C79AE2428F95E8F37111AD1CD5.description: Use cardinal and intermediate directions and simple grids to locate and describe places on maps and globes.

51F64376D19D46648B71CE894E10F51B.description: Interpret maps that include a title, legend, compass rose, and grid.

FA0ACA849F764FBFB0A2B4FCC1FA4604.description: Construct maps that include a title, legend, compass rose, and grid.

6512457F438E4AE196D9EE411FACA488.description: Create timelines and other visual organizers to sequence and represent historical figures, relationships, or chronological events.

7D6FFCEA40804FE0BA9EEA5D701FC4F8.description: Select and use appropriate tools and technologies to accomplish tasks.

22C6A82C8D6B48AC9486E9F27E9B9F47.description: Use appropriate terms or expressions to describe periods of time. Examples: decade, generation, century, when the Earth was new, in the time of our ancestors.

FC545C586CAA4AA28AD4D6CEB8AE4C53.description: Organize and record information in a variety of formats and reference sources appropriately. Examples: maps, charts, outlines, concept maps.

0210CCC1956C4869AF41C66D2578BE07.description:
Select information from oral, visual, material,
print, or electronic sources.
Examples: maps, atlases.

9FAB0D6C5FE74BFF8E935649963E741A.description: Negotiate constructively with others to build consensus.

C60612840E3B4039B5A1205FBA56F46F.description: Make decisions that reflect care, concern, and responsibility for the environment.

6020122B003F49C38243BFF9E53267C9.description: Interact fairly and respectfully with others.

1F419471B2394FDEB372A8E4D34E8293.description:
Collaborate with others to share ideas,
decisions, and responsibilities in groups.
